name: Open Foris Collect
description: Open Foris Collect is the main entry point for data collected in field-based inventories. It provides a fast, easy, flexible way to set up a survey with a user-friendly interface. Collect handles multiple data types and complex validation rules, all in a multilanguage environment. It allows to generate mobile-friendly surveys (Collect Mobile) as well as web-based data collection activities.

sdgs.relevance:
Under the framework for Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation in Developing Countries (REDD+), many countries are making progress e.g. in developing and submitting to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) their Forest Reference (Emission) Levels (FREL/FRLs), and reporting on REDD+ results through annexes to Biennial Update Reports (BUR).  As of the end of 2022, of the 56 countries that submitted a REDD+ reference level to the UNFCCC, 49 countries (88 percent) used one or more Open Foris tools. With the latest submissions in 2022, 66% of reporting countries used Open Foris Collect jointly with Collect Earth in their data collection process. In addition, a total of 28 countries has used OF Collect in their National Forest Inventory (NFI) for collecting field data. 

OF Collect has been used in Chad for woodfuel assessment in areas surrounding refugee camps, and OF Collect Mobile has been used to gather transaction data and thus to ensure food supply in rural Bangladesh.  In addition, OF tools are used for example for socio-economic inventory in Mongolia and dairy industry survey in Kazakhstan.

NonPII.nonPIIAccessMechanism:
Data collected by OF Collect can be exported to Excel/CSV format.
The format used to share data amongst Collect installations is exported as a human-readable XML format.
The database generated by Collect can also be exported as a SQL batch export including the SQL DB structure and the data.

Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC)
- Change management using version control (github.com/openforis/collect)
- Test driven development using automated tests (unit and integration tests)
- Continous Integration & Continous Deployment (CI/CD) (done with actions in GitHub https://github.com/openforis/collect/actions)
- Code review (pull requests review in GitHub)
- Code refactoring (once in a while

like https://github.com/openforis/collect/pull/110)
- Rapid application development
- Agile development

Architectural Design
- Architectural Principles
- Modularity and Maintainability (Collect is divided into several Maven modules

collect-core is re-used in Collect Earth and Collect Mobile)
- Reusability and Extensibility
- Accountability & Non-repudiability
- Security & Consented Access (Restful API protected by Spring Security)
- Universal Access & Open APIs
- Microservices architecture
- SOLID principles of object oriented programming

- Multitier architecture
- Model–view–controller
- Representational state transfer (REST)
- Publish-subscribe

- Monolithic application

Best practices to help secure your IT resources:
- Create strong passwords for username/ password authentication
- Enable resource access authorization i.e. access control rights/ permissions
- Leverage IT auditing
- Protect data in transit (encrypt data in transit using TLS/SSL

use X.509 certificates to authenticate the remote end)
